question: What are the key datasets used to evaluate the ScoreGrad method, and what are their characteristics in terms of dimensions, domain, frequency, and time steps?
answer: The ScoreGrad method is evaluated on six key datasets: Exchange, Solar, Electricity, Traffic, Taxi, and Wikipedia. Their characteristics are as follows:\\n- Exchange: 8 dimensions, positive real numbers domain, daily frequency, 6071 time steps, prediction length of 30.\\n- Solar: 137 dimensions, positive real numbers domain, hourly frequency, 7009 time steps, prediction length of 24.\\n- Electricity: 370 dimensions, positive real numbers domain, hourly frequency, 5833 time steps, prediction length of 24.\\n- Traffic: 963 dimensions, values between 0 and 1, hourly frequency, 4001 time steps, prediction length of 24.\\n- Taxi: 1214 dimensions, natural numbers domain, 30-minute frequency, 1488 time steps, prediction length of 24.\\n- Wikipedia: 2000 dimensions, natural numbers domain, daily frequency, 792 time steps, prediction length of 30.
reference: \"ScoreGrad: Multivariate Probabilistic Time Series Forecasting with Continuous Energy-based Generative Models\" - Section: \"Datasets description and evaluation metrics\" - Table: Table 2 \"Properties of the datasets, including dimensions, domain, frequency, time steps and prediction length.\"

question: How does ScoreGrad perform compared to other methods in terms of $\\text{CRPS}_{\\text{sum}}$ on the Solar dataset?
answer: ScoreGrad achieves a $\\text{CRPS}_{\\text{sum}}$ of 0.268±0.021 for VP SDE, 0.277±0.011 for VE SDE, and 0.256±0.015 for sub-VP SDE on the Solar dataset. These results are better than other methods like TimeGrad (0.287±0.020), Transformer-MAF (0.301±0.014), and Vec-LSTM variants.
reference: \"ScoreGrad: Multivariate Probabilistic Time Series Forecasting with Continuous Energy-based Generative Models\" - Section: \"Results\" - Table: Table 3 \"Comparison of $\\text{CRPS}_{\\text{sum}}$ of the methods on six real-world datasets (lower is better).\"

question: What are the CRPS values achieved by the proposed \\ourmodel\\ on the Traffic dataset for prediction lengths of 8 and 16 compared to other models?
answer: On the Traffic dataset, with a prediction length of 8, \\ourmodel\\ achieves CRPS values of $0.207_{\\nolinebreak\\pm.003}$, which is better than NVAE ($0.593_{\\nolinebreak\\pm.004}$), $\\beta$-TCVAE ($0.894_{\\nolinebreak\\pm.003}$), and other models listed. For a prediction length of 16, \\ourmodel\\ achieves CRPS values of $0.200_{\\nolinebreak\\pm.014}$, outperforming NVAE ($0.589_{\\nolinebreak\\pm.001}$), $\\beta$-TCVAE ($0.893_{\\nolinebreak\\pm.002}$), and the remaining models.
reference: Title: Generative Time Series Forecasting with Diffusion, Denoise, and Disentanglement; Section: Experiment Results, Table 2

question: What is the effect of using the coupled diffusion probabilistic model on the MSE performance of \\ourmodel\\ on the Electricity dataset?
answer: The coupled diffusion probabilistic model significantly improves \\ourmodel\\'s MSE performance on the Electricity dataset. When the diffusion model is not used (\\ourmodel$_{-\\text{CDM}}$), the MSE is higher at $0.365_{\\nolinebreak\\pm.025}$ for a prediction window of 16 compared to \\ourmodel\\'s $0.308_{\\nolinebreak\\pm.030}$. Similar improvements are seen in other prediction horizons.
reference: Title: Generative Time Series Forecasting with Diffusion, Denoise, and Disentanglement; Section: Model Analysis, Table referenced in the text about ablation study

question: What is the error reduction achieved by DiffSTG in terms of Continuous Ranked Probability Score (CRPS) on the PEMS08 dataset compared to existing methods?
answer: DiffSTG achieves a 14.3% reduction in Continuous Ranked Probability Score (CRPS) on the PEMS08 dataset compared to existing probabilistic methods.
reference: \"Extensive experiments validate that DiffSTG reduces the Continuous Ranked Probability Score (CRPS)... on three real-world datasets.\" - DiffSTG: Probabilistic Spatio-Temporal Graph Forecasting with Denoising Diffusion Models, Abstract.

question: What are the improvements in Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) achieved by DiffSTG on the AIR-GZ dataset over existing probabilistic methods?
answer: DiffSTG improves the Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) by 2.4% on the AIR-GZ dataset compared to existing probabilistic methods.
reference: \"...Extensive experiments validate that DiffSTG reduces...Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) by 2\"-7% over existing methods on three real-world datasets.\" - DiffSTG: Probabilistic Spatio-Temporal Graph Forecasting with Denoising Diffusion Models, Abstract.
